list.item: Go after a still with deputy sheriff and other teachers -

div1.p: Dearest family - It's about 10 p.m. Friday and though I have to be ready by 6 in the morning to go to Sevierville with Emily & Mr. Cresswell in the Huff car - will dash off a brief account of the exciting events since I wrote you the early part of the week - Just wait till you hear about the event!

Our letters are so long in getting across - have sent two sets of kodak pictures now & hope some in the second will charm & thrill you as I have been! Yes the hills do look high - you know they are mountains - & Gatlinburg itself is about 1700 ft. elevation. As to the discipline - well they all think I'm hard on them because I make them behave & keep them in for lessons - all of which seems to be rather an
unusual process - However in spite of the cross looks & tears shall continue to try to get them to learn a few things. They certainly do not compare favorably as to knowledge with our western youngsters - and no wonder judging from the conditions that prevail in the schools in these mts. - one consists of two teachers & two hundred pupils - what do you think of that?

Yes the laundry bag - which I presume is for handkerchiefs was in the package & thought I had mentioned it - for I like it very much. The white dress came & Mary Ogle will fix it for me - Am quite crazy about these dresses - so comfortable and neat are they!

Mrs. Helmick is a Pi Phi - the wife of Gen. Helmick and has been all over the world with him I guess.
She has lived among these people & they are all very devoted to her. Through her efforts principally I believe the school was started & for the first five years of its existence she was the main one to push things She superintended the building of this house and built the little bungalow where Mary Ogle lives & which she later sold to the Pi Phi's.

What color did you paint the upstairs? Hope it was dry for the party! Tell me about it & the visit of the Glasiers. Don't know what the Cavanagh's thought of my going to Fannie but imagine it suited all around - for decorators arrived the morning I left as the whole house inside & out is being done over.
Do hope pa takes a trip - you must pa - sure!
You all sound as busy as I am - & busy is the word. And all these other people here have so much time on hand oh just loads of it! Am so glad Victoria is progressing & hope she is up & around soon!

Lida sent me a nice letter not long ago - will have to get another letter written next week for the girls - will you let them have the pictures - borrow them I mean and would like the Seattle Pi Phis to see them too - either you or one of them (Tacoma Pi Phi) could send them to Ruth D. as long as she is the president. 6554 18th Av. N.E.

Will now proceed to tell of my doings beginning Wednesday as my last was written Tues.
Emily and I were alone as Evelyn did not get back from Knoxville as she had expected - Aunt Lizzie was here of course - Right after school we come home & get busy although it's a grand p.m. & we are anxious to walk. However I settle right down in my room (which I shall describe some day as soon as these exciting thing that occupy my attention cease) and correct papers - make out test questions & then write a long & much delayed letter to Fannie. By that time supper was ready for us which we enjoyed on the back porch. Then we took a little stroll up Pi Phi lane & got back just in time to welcome three ladies from the hotel who wanted to use the phone principally -
Next my Tom McCarter arrived for help with his Latin & thus the evening flitted by -

Thursday - was the day of days & you'll never guess how it ended - for never in my wildest flights of fancy had I pictured myself in a raid on a still! Now what have you to say? Well to begin at the first - Since Institute was to occupy our Saturday & the preparations for the party & the party itself most of our spare time Fri. - Emily & I hustled home & got busy doing the sweeping & dusting downstairs - in our bedrooms - the halls & stairs. About 5:30 I roamed out on the porch where sat Evelyn (who got home the day before) Abbie & Aunt Lizzie. My room was not yet dusted & the dustcloth still in
my hand but I dropped down into one of our comfortable rockers & conversed. Pretty soon Harrison (our man about the place you know & as I told you in one letter a deputy sheriff) was seen driving Dan from the road up into the school grounds & the hack (as a two seated buggy is so designated) attached to him (Dan). This hack has been out of commission for months & H. was just bringing it home. Evelyn said "Why don't you girls get Harrison to take you for a little ride before dinner?" Of course we were charmed & calling Emily - Abbie & I rushed across the grounds to tell H. not to unhitch Dan. We coaxed him to take us & piling into the dirty back seat we began chattering away & finally got to the subject of stills by the time we were on the road - Well one remark brought forth another & Harrison confided to us that he was going after a still about two miles off the next night. Of course we wanted to go - but then there was our party - Well why not go then & there if it was only two miles away? The three of us were too much for him & he said "All right!" & then added - "We'll stop & get Mr. Cresswell!" So we did tearing him away from his dinner I imagine - We just told him to come on for a ride as the boys were around - Then driving on a little farther to the store we stopped & here were made preparations by dear Harrison. Really he simply convulsed us - he was so mysterious &
cautious through the whole performance - "just perfect" as Emily said. He got out & went in the store - while we gleefully told Mr. C. what was doing - he was quite thrilled too as it was a new experience for him as well as us. H. then came back with a huge flashlight & a bag of candy for us maidens. Then Mr. Huff comes along in his machine whom H. stops - then climbs in & disappears down the road with him. We meanwhile giggle & eat the giddy gum drops and other kinds (name unknown but of gorgeous color) & Mr. C. has the happy thought of buying a huge watermelon which is put in the back. We send word to Evelyn by the small boy Rellie (Mary's) not to wait supper for us.
H. now returns with a small covered basket & goes in the store - comes out - puts basket on bench in front of store - summons Mr. C. to a mysterious conference at one side of the road - after which the two climb to the front seat & off we start down the road towards Sevierville - When we get out of the burg a ways - H. gets out & prowls along at the rear smoking cigarettes (I have a snap of him which I'll send in due time) At last after about two miles of bumpy ups & downs we turn around & drive close to one side of the road. Here we get out & the men proceed to unhitch Dan. H. leads him off a ways & ties him under a tree. While thus engaged two wagons
drawn by mules come around the bend in the road & H. immediately conceals himself in the undergrowth along the river bank. When this danger is over we all scramble down to the river - which was quite shallow - rocky & narrow. We are to cross it stepping lightly from stone to stone. Well Abbie makes it beautifully - I'm in that old white dress & my white pumps & before I get across slip in neatly to my ankles - Emily also steps off - She is wearing French heels! Safely on the other side we scramble through dense underbrush along the river H. in the lead peering intently hither & yon & stopping occasionally. Then we strike right up the side of a steep hill where the laurels are very thick - logs to climb over - & all sorts of twigs catching at our hair & dress. H. now turns & whispers to us to wait. So we stand in a little group expectant & atwitter for about ten minutes until he stealthily returns & gives the word to start. Finally we strike a trail through this dense underbrush a very new one too - which we follow to the edge of a little patch of corn. Here we can see it dimly winding in & around the stalks & on we go. It leads us to a branch (a little little creek) Here we continue climbing over around & under logs - branches - stones & trees - Part of the time we
walk in the creek itself. H. every little while stops - listens & peers everywhere & points out places occasionally where he says they have been "hidin' out" & sure enough you can see remains of fires & flattened grass. It gets wilder & wilder & darker for the branch is in a very narrow & thickly overgrown "holler". I'm a perfect wreck as to my shoes - skirts - hair & stockings but keep right after H. - we must have gone all of a mile up this romantically wild spot when once more H. halts us & goes forward - By this time we have had strong whiffs of whiskey & H. knows positively he's on the trail - Yes & right ahead is a little semicircle where are several barrels & the furnace -
The still itself however is gone - H. whispers all this to us - & that no doubt it's hidden somewhere nearby - While they (the men) are pulling fodder. Pulling fodder is stripping the leaves off the cornstalks for the cattle. Everyone is doing that now - The stalks with the ears will stand until the frosts. "In about two weeks" H. said "they'll be back at work again & then I'll come & get them!" However he had expected to find it or them as I guess he had received pretty good & reliable information as to their whereabouts. We girls were disappointed not to have gotten the still itself but no doubt things turned out for the best - as sometimes there's shooting & it's risky Evelyn told us afterwards. It was rather dusky go -
ing back down that wild trail - mostly jumping over logs - & all the time going down hill - Oh how hot & dirty & mussy we were - Finally after one last wild dash through the undergrowth we got to the place to cross the river - Here Mr. C. Emily & I performed several stunts on the rocks finally getting wet to the knees! but we got over - back to the hack & our lovely watermelon. As soon as Dan was hitched the feast began - What a picture we must have made. Fortunately it was dark & no one cared for the flashlight except to get watermelon. Dan was pretty impatient to be gone after his long wait & went home quite briskly. We got H. to promise to take us when he went after the still again & saying goodnight to the gents we ran joyfully up the road to the house where Evelyn had saved us lovely cocoa, salad - & cake. She thought it was a wonderful & unusual adventure but also thought we ought not to go again as it didn't look well for the school nor was it very safe. Poor Mary - when she washes my garments black as the ground half way up - what will she think! for of course no one at the burg except Evelyn will ever know that we did more than go for a ride & cooling our melon by the river got wet!! Such is life!

Well I must hasten on & stop -
as its getting late & 5 o'clock will soon be here. Have been just dying to tell you all this before but just couldn't get it in last night for the trip was the most strenuous thing I've done yet & bed seemed good!

The chief event was our party - the Five Senses as I told you it was to be - About thirty-five youngsters came - We began at 7:30 & by 9:30 all were gone - The girls of the club - Evergreen Club - were supposed to be the hostesses & 4 or 5 of them were here after school getting the stuff ready & fixing tally cards - It went off beautifully & I think was a novel & interesting occasion to them. They worked in pairs - Drew partners thusly - Curtains hang be-
tween hall & living room & the girls on one side stuck their thumbs through for the boys on the other side to choose - The first prize consisted of 2 little pieces of apple pie all nicely done up in a box - white tissue paper etc. The booby prize was a little green tomatoe done up in much paper - Some songs finished the program & they all went home gayly - and now I'm going to bid you all a fond goodnight & go to bed too - Tell dear Mabel the list of plays & the book have come and I'm very much indebted to her - To whom do I owe the money?
With loads of love to you all as ever - Ruth-
P.S. The papers have come - the social item was rich! R.S.
